awd_titl_txt: SEP Collaborative: Development of Economically Viable, Highly Efficient Organic Photovoltaic Solar Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Sustainable Energy pathways (SEP) Program, under the umbrella of the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability (SEES) initiative, will support the research program of Prof. Luping Yu and co-workers at the University of Chicago, Prof. Yang Yang and co-workers at the University of California at Los Angeles (UCLA), and Prof. Lin Chen and co-workers at Northwestern University. The objective of this multidisciplinary collaborative project is to develop organic solar cells with power conversion efficiency competitive with amorphous inorganic solar cells.  Novel materials (both donor and acceptor materials) with the best power conversion efficiencies and controlled absorption windows will be synthesized.  Detailed structural and spectroscopic studies will be performed to probe and understand exciton generation, charge separation, and transport mechanism in these newly developed materials, which will form the foundation for device fabrication.  Novel geometryies of tandem solar cells will be developed to maximize solar energy conversion.  Close collaborations with active feedback among the team will lead to rapid realization of the research goal.

The overall viability of organic photovoltaics (OPV) as a sustainable energy technology will be assessed based on their environmental, health, and economic impacts via collaboration with a Dr. Peter Sinsheimer on urban planning, Prof. Zhu Yifang on public health, and Mr. Timothy Malloy on societal impact.  Issues associated with technology diffusion and possible commercial, institutional, legal, policy, technological, and cultural barriers associated with the design, development, and adoption of new sustainable technologies will be evaluated experimentally and/or based on viable models.  This collaborative effort will be used as a platform to attract underrepresented undergraduate students to the research area of sustainable energy pathways.  The project will provide great opportunity to educate and train graduate students and postdoctoral associates in system-based research in the area of sustainable energy pathways.

If this project succeeds, it will result in alternative solar energy harvest materials and devices that can be manufactured in an environmentally friendly approach, with flexibility, and at a low cost. It will change the landscape of renewable energy and exert significant impact on sustainable economic development and environmental protection.  The resulting technology may penetrate into our daily life, as it may be used in a wide range of electronic devices like portable battery chargers, energy saving computer displays, and house decorations. Students working on this project will be prepared to become leaders in renewable energy research and development.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome Report

Intellectual Merit:

This project is to develop organic solar cells with power conversion efficiency competitive with amorphous inorganic solar cells. Novel materials synthesis, device engineering, detailed structural and spectroscopic studies have been performed to the device maximize solar energy conversion. Close collaborations with active feedback among different teams has lead to rapid realization of the research goal. The research represents a new front for high efficiency solar cell research and integrates both chemistry and material science to generate new perspectives in science and offer solutions to challenging issues in sustainable energy.

The achievements include:

- Effect of direct ozone exposure on OPV films (P3HT:PC71BM)

a) Degradation of organic films and anodes are the major factor that affect device performance and hence, we conclude that direct exposure of OPV films to ozone damages the OPV film and causes rapid film dysfunction.

b) We have obtained very reproducible results establishing relationship of decay rate with time and strength of ozone exposure. The devices decay to 0% efficiency in 12 hours under 300 ppb concentrations and in 6 hours under 600 ppb concentrations. This shows that there is an inverse linear relation between efficiency decay rate and ozone exposure at high concentrations.

c) We conclude that the films degrade under ambient ozone conditions. The devices decay to 0% efficiency in 28 hours under 70 ppb concentration (ambient), which is much faster than expected.

- Effect of ozone exposure on complete OPV devices (with coated anode materials)

We observed that the devices show an efficiency of 4.16% with standard deviation of 0.12%, after 42.8 hours of exposure, hence concluding that the anode materials (Al and MoO3) impart significant robustness to the OPV device against ozone oxidation.

- The diffusion analysis research drew upon existing literature which demonstrates that the nature and rate of diffusion of innovations depends heavily upon the broader environment in which the potential technology adopter is situated.  The following significant conclusions regarding diffusion of BIPV resulted from the analysis of the legal, historical, economic, social science and technical literature through the lens of the conceptual system model:

a) OPV has several technological attributes that make it better suited for BIPV than conventional PV, including good low light performance, more stable conversion efficiency at higher ambient temperatures, lower cost, transparency, and flexibility. 

 b) Achieving broad adoption of BIPV in general and OPV-based BIPV in particular will depend upon acceptance by real estate developers and owners. 

c) There appear to be limited training or educational programs on new technology for building designers and construction contractors. 

 

Broader Impact:

Under the sponsorship of the NSF award, the collaborative groups have carried out training for 3 PhD students (Mr. Sheng-Yung Chang, Mr. Lei Meng and Mr. Tiangyang Wang), one master student (Mr. Aneeket Palankar), and one undergraduate student (Mr. Ruifeng Zhang). The training provided students the fundamental concepts and skills of general research as well as stimulating their interest in applied scientific research. A female student from the Physics Department of Pomona College (a top Liberal and Art College in the nation) -Ms. Sabrina Li was trained in UCLA on polymer solar cell device fabrication and characterization. Sabrina will continue her training and research in the coming year. We also have a visiting PhD student from India -Vishal Bharti in the project. Mr. Matthew Reiser, a UCLA undergraduate economics student, participated in the diffusion research aspects of the project, and conducted independent empirical research regarding the efficacy of local incentive programs for PV and OPV cells in two California cities. The project also included training for four law students (Kari Hicks, Jeffrey Asay, Julia Nick, and Michelle Cuozzo) in policy research and analysis skills, and enhanced their interest in interdisciplinary research linking science, engineering and law.

This collaborative effort has been used as a platform to attract underrepresented undergraduate students to the research area of sustainable energy path. It provides great opportunity to educate graduate students and postdoctoral associates for future challenge in sustainable energy pathway. This education process has also been enhanced by a set of webinars on the current science and technology of OPV as well as on evaluating the viability of OPV as a sustainable technology. These webinars are in turn used as a basis for a high-school science module.

The PI and Co-PI has participated NSF workshops on PV in general and on OPV to disseminate the research to broader society.

Publication list:

Jing Gao, Wei Chen, Leitan Dou, Chun-Chao Chen, Wei-Hsuan Cheng, Yongsheng Liu, Gang Li, Yang Yang. Adv. Mater. 2014, 26, 3142.

Leitan Dou, Yongsheng Liu, Zhirou Hong, Gang Li, Yang Yang. Chem. Rev. 2015, 115, 12633.

You Seung Rim, Kyung-Chul Ok, Yang Michael Yang, Huajun Chen, Sang-Hoon Bae, Chen Wang, Yu Huang, Jin-Seong Park, Yang Yang. ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces, 2014, 8, 14665.


Last Modified: 11/22/2016
Modified by: Yang Yang
